div1.p: Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State Washington.
Subject. Fiscal Settlement of the estate of the late William Parker.
Synopsis. died at Robertsport, Grand Cape Moount Territory Liberia Nov. 14, 1900.
No. 80. Consular. Consulate General of the United States, Monrovia, Liberia, October 10, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir In transmitting my final report of the death and settlement of the estate of the late William Parker, deceased, who died at Robertsport, Grand Cape Mount Territory Liberia, November 14, 1900. I have the honor to say that I can only transmit such a report as has been forwarded to me by Jas. H. Lewis, the local Administrator of the effects of the deceased.
From correspondence between him

him and myself (copies of which have long since been transmitted to the Department) you will observe that I used every possible effort to prevent Mr. Lewis from disposing of the effects of the deceased.

As I have previously reported to the Department, the local authorities, at Robertsport, set up the claim that the deceased, William Parker, was a Liberian citizen, and as such, they had a right to administer upon his effects as a Liberian citizen, turning over the proceeds of his effects to me less their charge, commissions and expenses.
After Mr. Lewis had forwarded to me a very indefinite report and statement of the estate, which reached me

me early in April 1901, you will see b reference to a copy of my despatch No. 13, Miscellaneous, of April 16, 1901, to the State Department, Monrovia, that I setforth many irregularities in the report of the Administrator, and asked the assistance of the Liberian Government in having them rectified.

To this despatch No. 13, above refined to the Liberian Government has never directly replied, but did write Mr. Lewis to report to me, hence, I have since received receipts to the amount of the disbursements; but as these receipts were, with but few exceptions, all written and signed in the hand writing of the Administrator himself; several signed by mark, without any witness, thereto

thereto, they appeared to me to be rather suspicious, hence I called upon, and showed the receipts to the President, (who is de facto Secretary of State) who returned the suspicious receipts to the local Superintendent, at Robertsport, to have them verified, consolidated into one, signed by one of the recipiants and returned to me through the Department of State, Monrovia.

After transmitting copies of correspondence between Mr. Lewis, the Department of State, Monrovia, and myself relative to this matter; and informing the Department of State, Washington, relative to the conflicting claims of the local authorities and myself, as to the nationality of

of the deceased; and having received from the Department of State, Washington in Diplomatic Despatch No 66, May 1, 1901, a request that I procure and transmit to said Department a copy of the Liberian Statutes, relating to the naturalization, in Liberia of citizen of the United States of African descent, I have since transmitting copies of said statutes, awaited instructions from Washington, as to whether, in the opinion of the Department, under existing Liberian statutes, the deceased, William Parker, was a Liberian or an American citizen. Further, whether I should press my request, by demands, made in my No. 13, of April 16, 1901, of the Liberian Government,

Government, relative to Jas. H. Lewis or relinquish them, by failing to press them. You will doubtless observe, in my fourth statement and request, in said No. 14, of April 16, 1901, that I have no possible means. beyond circumstantial evidence, (the most plausible of which would hardly convict a Liberian in a Liberian Court, contended against by a foreign Government) of proving that Jas. H. Lewis, did really come into possession of the £30 Sterling and the two American $10, gold pieces; received from me the morning of the day he sailed from Monrovia for Robertsport Liberia.
While I have been waiting for the above desired instructions, I have been somewhat at

at a loss, whether to report the deceased, William Parker, as a deceased American citizen or not. Hence my delay in officially reporting his demise and the final settlement of his estate, as it has been transmitted to me, by the local Administrator. I have further to advise you that the deceased, William Parker, carried a Life Policy, the which he had left in America, I think, with his wife. Since his death Wm. R. Morris Esq. Building, Minneappolis, Minnesota, consel for Mrs. Parker has forwarded a blank, disering certain evidence of the death &c. of William Parker, necessary in prosecuting her claim for said Life Policy. This evidence was

was certified to by three local officials at Robertsport; the official character of which had to be certified to by me. Hence the intem in said account, in aluding the Clerk's official character, in the Inventory, for certifying to the official character of four officials.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
Enclosures. 1. Statement of Account. Estate of the late William Parker &c 2. Copy of Inventory of the ffects of the late WIlliam Parker. 3. Report of the death of William Parker.
